unnormalised: The lockdown in 2020 was a real eye-opener for my family, especially regarding education. My younger sister, Aisha, was suddenly stuck at home with her Std. 8 syllabus staring her in the face. DPS, Bangalore, like many schools, scrambled to shift online. We quickly realized that the 1 textbook per subject approach wasn't cutting it.
normalised: The lockdown in two thousand and twenty was a real eye-opener for my family, especially regarding education. My younger sister, Aisha, was suddenly stuck at home with her standard eight syllabus staring her in the face. D-P-S, Bangalore, like many schools, scrambled to shift online. We quickly realized that the one textbook per subject approach wasn't cutting it.

unnormalised: Initially, Aisha struggled. Lectures felt impersonal on Zoom, and the constant screen time gave her headaches. Mom and I started researching alternatives, and that's when we stumbled upon several EdTech platforms. Byju's was the first name that popped up, but the subscription fees were steep - approx. Rs. 50,000/year! We then explored Vedantu and Unacademy, which offered more flexible options, including free trial classes.
normalised: Initially, Aisha struggled. Lectures felt impersonal on Zoom, and the constant screen time gave her headaches. Mom and I started researching alternatives, and that's when we stumbled upon several E-D-Tech platforms. Byju's was the first name that popped up, but the subscription fees were steep - approximately rupees fifty thousand per year! We then explored Vedantu and Unacademy, which offered more flexible options, including free trial classes.

unnormalised: Aisha really took to Unacademy. The interactive quizzes and the ability to ask questions in real-time made learning more engaging. She even started watching YouTube tutorials from creators like Physics Wallah. Suddenly, concepts that seemed daunting in class became much clearer. Her score in the Science test jumped from 65% to 85% in just 2 months.

unnormalised: We also discovered some amazing educational apps. For Maths, Photomath was a lifesaver, instantly solving complex equations and showing the step-by-step solutions. Duolingo turned out to be great for brushing up on her French lessons. It wasn’t just about academics though. Aisha also started taking online coding classes on WhiteHat Jr.

unnormalised: Online learning isn't perfect, but it's definitely transformed education in India. It has made quality content accessible to students, irrespective of their location or socioeconomic background. From interactive video lectures to personalized learning paths, EdTech is giving students like Aisha the tools they need to succeed in the 21st century. Plus, it preponed my mastery of Zoom to a level that impressed even my techie friends.
